712004f-a.text:
128-36 West 3lst Street, south side, between 8,9,6th Avenues, the Central Needle Trades Construction School is housed in the 17th
story building on this site.
Board of Education, N.Y.C,
1920

712003f.text:
109 West 31st Street, north side, west of Sixth Ave. (right, not seen). The excavation on the right include:buildings at the N.W. corner of this point. They were Nos. 103 and 107 West 31st Street and 521 to 525 (old Nos.).Sixth Ave. Upon this excavation stands the 25-story Greely Square Building. No. 109 in conjunction with 111 were demolished at a later date and the open space used by the Nevin Bus Lines in 1936 as a terminal.
This set consists of a negative and a positive.
May 24, 1926.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

712005f-a.text:
145-129 West 31st Street, north side, between Seventh and Sixth Avenues.  Nos. 143-137 are the St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic School and Church.
June 15, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

709418f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from a point between W. 31st and 32nd Streets, and across the latter to Greeley Square, showing Manhattan's famous shopping center. At the left margin are Gimbels and Saks department stores.
The modern white center structure is the Herald Square Building and was erected several years ago. This site formerly was occupied by the Herald and which in turn had succeeded the old 71st Reg. Armory. To the right is the Hotel McAlpin.
View No. 2 is photographed from the S.W. corner of 32nd Street and shows Greeley Square cluttered with subway building materials. The "El" structure and its 33rd Street station will be demolished in the latter part of March and Easter will see the entire Sixth Avenue 'El" completely relegated to the past.
February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr

The same after removal of "El".
P. L. Sperr September 7, 1940
